lead_paragraph: THERE are exploding garbage trucks in the new season of ''The Sopranos,'' as well as an image of Tony lying on his kitchen floor in a puddle of blood. There are clips from the classic gangster movie ''The Public Enemy'' and a reference to a piece of capicola as Tony's Proustian madeleine, evoking memories of his boyhood introduction to violence. And there is a wake that is vicious, funny and finally sad in its heartbreaking honesty. ''The Sopranos,'' a pop-culture phenomenon and a plain old hit, begins its third season on Sunday night with back-to-back episodes on HBO that display more wit, emotion, humanity and brutality than ever. Even measured against insanely high expectations, the series is as good as it has ever been.
abstract: Caryn James reviews start of third season of David Chase's HBO series The Sopranos, starring James Gandolfini and Edie Falco; photos (M)
